text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with pork belly with celery root
puree that's where i do not let the
unremarkable name fool you this gorgeous
fall appetizer was tremendously
delicious and pork belly is one of those
things people see on TV maybe you've
seen Bourdain waxing poetic about it
travelling through Asia or you saw one
of those kids make it on Top Chef you
know the one with the tattoos and you
thought to yourself man that looks good
I wonder what's up with that eye but
it's really hard to work with no it's
incredibly easy and this is how you do
it
so first up of course we're going to
need a piece of pork belly and if you're
thinking man that sure looks like bacon
there's a reason for that this is the
exact same piece of meat they make bacon
with so we got that going for us and we
basically have two sides kind of a meaty
side and a fatty side and speaking of
the fatty side please note the skin has
been removed from this yes there are
some amazing things you can do with pork
skin but just now in this particular
recipe but anyway we're going to take
our piece of pork belly sands skin and
we're going to season it up very
generously with some kosher salt a whole
bunch of freshly ground black pepper and
a little touch of smoked paprika it's
just going to give it a hint of
sweetness and a teensy tiny bit of
smokiness in the background and once our
pork belly has been salt peppered and
paprika down both sides we will begin
the wrapping process and you can just do
this in foil but what I'm going to do is
start with a piece of parchment paper
first I want to kind of create an extra
membrane around the pork before we wrap
it the aluminum and actually let me flip
this over so the fat sides down and once
that's wrapped in the parchment we will
wrap this in not one but two layers of
aluminum foil so we'll place that down
we'll wrap it in our first piece of foil
and generally I do like using the
heavy-duty foil here but a couple pieces
of regular foil will work perfectly oh
and one other thing I generally like to
end up with the fat side up which I
don't believe I did here I think I lost
tracked which really is no big deal
because pork belly is such a fatty piece
of meat but in general when we roast
things we prefer the fattier stuff on
top so it can kind of self based but
like I said that's not really a major
factor here and once we have that
encased in parchment and wrapped in foil
we will place that in a heavy-duty
roasting pan or baking dish
at which point is ready for a very
gentle very slow roasting yes
low and low that is the tempo so we're
going to place this in a 200 degree oven
and roast it for five and a half hours
and we'll come back five and a half
hours later take it out and it's going
to pretty much look exactly the same and
at this point I would love to unwrap
this and show you what it looks like but
we can't okay you don't want to move on
to the last steps of this recipe until
the pork is cold I guess theoretically
you could use this now but I think it's
better if you follow this procedure so
we will let that cool on the stovetop
for a couple hours and then we'll pop it
in the fridge preferably overnight at
which point we'll pull it out and move
on to the final steps and because we
cook this at such a low temperature as
we unwrap this you're going to notice
that pork did not shrink that much of
course you're going to see a little bit
of that natural gelatin and some fat of
course but you really should not lose a
lot of volume with that meat and
speaking of the fat do not discard that
what we do is we'll use that to crisp
this up so save the fat and then what
we'll do is we'll take a knife and cut
this into serving size pieces and from a
pieces big you could probably get six or
eight portions because of the fat
content it's a very rich piece of meat
so a little bit goes a long way and then
once we have it portioned out what we
want to do is take a knife and score the
fat side again one side is going to be
kind of meteor one sides going to be
kind of fattier so take a knife and cut
across about every eighth of an inch
cutting down about an eighth of an inch
into the fat and we'll go both
directions and that's going to help that
surface crisp up it's going to help some
of that fat render out and once that's
done you could just serve this whole
piece as is but I'm actually going to
cut it into three smaller pieces when it
comes to crispy pork belly in a pan
surface area is your friend and then
this is up to you but I do like to give
it a little extra salt so we'll season
that up a little bit which way we'll
head over to the stove where I've melted
a little bit of that reserved pork fat
over medium heat and we will place our
pieces of pork belly fat side down and
I'm home alone so I'm just going to do
one serving and basically once this is
heated through and those surfaces are
nicely caramelized you're ready to serve
and one trick I love to do with that fat
side down is play some kind of light
weight on top here I'm just using a big
ramekin you could use a pot or a pan or
small plate anything like that and that
way it's going to make that bottom
surface get a little more crusty push
out a little more that rendered fat
we'll go ahead and turn that over
and you can see just how gorgeous that
gets and again I'm a medium heat but if
you have to adjust that down a little
bit go ahead and really the only rule is
you have to cook that side as long as
the meats heated you could serve it but
I really do like to make sure all the
services are browned and then once I've
gotten a little bit of color on those
other sides I do like to finish off with
that scored fat side down give it a
couple last minutes of crispy time at
which point we're pretty much ready to
serve so we'll transfer that onto some
paper towel to drain for a minute while
we set up our plate featuring celery
root puree and if you're not down with
celery root you're not down it is
amazingly delicious stuff and basically
all this is is boiled in mashed celery
root with a little bit of butter which
by the way I will show you in detail in
our next video so stay tuned for that
but I'm gonna put a nice big swipe of
that on the plate we'll place down our
pork belly and then to finish this
believe it or not I like to give it a
tiny drizzle of extra virgin olive oil I
know we got pork fat I know we got
butter in the celery root but I want to
complete this unholy trinity of fats
with a little bit of extra virgin olive
oil and then last but not least a little
more freshly ground black pepper and
that pork belly with celery root puree
is done and it's at these times I wish I
had a larger vocabulary so I could
adequately explain how amazing this is I
mean the combination of that rich fatty
crispy edged pork with that earthy
subtly sweet beautifully aromatic celery
root and like I said that little bit of
grassy peppery hit from the oil it's
just an otherworldly combination and
unlike some pork belly recipes you see
we didn't cook this to death during the
roasting process I'm not trying to eat
pulled pork here I want this pork to be
very tender but not falling apart all
right I want some twosome nough stew it
which is exactly what we have here and
believe me I'd love to go on and on
about how amazing this celery root is
but I don't want to steal my own thunder
because like I said that's going to be
the next video so stay tuned for that so
basically to summarize I was absolutely
thrilled with this sure took a while but
it was super easy amazing textures and
tastes and I thought it looked like a
million dollars I mean come on you
Instagram this thing tell me your foodie
friends aren't going to be totally jelly
for your belly you know they will so I
really do hope you give this a try head
over to food wishes comm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info
and as always enjoy
